results.title: Writers Talking
results.brief_description: An insightful series of documentary portraits of Australian writers made with the assistance of the Archival Film Program and Literary Arts Board of the Australia Council.

results.title: Roland Robinson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
A poet with a strong attachment to the Australian landscape, Roland Robinson has a deep interest in Aboriginal lore, and performs his poetry with a memorable verve.

results.title: Peter Porter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
From his book-crammed London flat, Peter Porter introduces a variety of his best-known poems and presents his accessible and humane intelligence.

results.title: Randolph Stow
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
Filmed on location in the landscapes of Suffolk and East Angliam, his present home, Randolf Stow talks of his life and shares examples of his poetry and prose.

results.title: David Malouf: an imaginary life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
Poet and novelist David Malouf was filmed in Tuscany, Italy, during the coldest winter there for 50 years, and in Sydney during a steamy summer. To write, he says, you must turn your back on even the most beautiful landscape. Malouf talks about the influences on his work and how he gets into the writing process.

results.title: Les Murray
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
Filmed at his home, a poetry reading and on his family’s farm in Northern NSW, Les Murray shares his love for poetry in this colourful and engaging portrait.

results.title: Battle for the Bulge
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty and Peter Batty Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Visions of War”.
December 1944 witnessed the last German offensive of the Second World War. The Battle of the Bulge, as this campaign in the Ardennes forests of Belgium and Luxembourg is now more familiarly known, was the biggest single pitched battle of the Western Front - more than a million troops took part. It was Hitler’s most desperate gamble of the war, he in fact planned its every move. This film uses current location filming and authentic historical film clips to document this battle. Portrays the heroism, as well as the confusion and humiliation, that characterised both the Allied and German troops.

results.title: Death railway
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visions of War”.
World War II prisoners of war recall building the infamous narrow-gauge railway through the almost impenetrable, disease infested jungles between Rangoon and Bangkok. Over 116,000 Australians, British, and Dutch lost their lives. Was this infamous railway a military necessity or a monument to brutality? The survivors (including Sir Edward Dunlop) tell a story of courage and resourcefulness in the face of a hostile environment and a ruthless enemy. Rare archival film was used in the compiling of this documentary, including a Japanese propaganda film on the treatment of prisoners of war. Contains some scenes in b&w. Narrated by Gerard Kennedy.

results.title: Birth of the bomb [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty and Peter Batty Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visions of War”.
This is the background story of the making of the first atomic bomb. The period covered is from 1938 to the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. German efforts to create an atomic bomb are described. The intensive research into the development of the bomb in the United States is dealt with extensively. Includes archival film and interviews with some of those involved. (Black and white version)
